Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of up flow catalytic fixed bed flow reactor for CO2 reduction. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Powder XRD patters of CeOx-SiO2 (blue), Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 (red) and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 (black); (b) small angle XRD patterns of SiO2 (black), CeO2-SiO2 (magenta), Ru-Fe3O4/SiO2 (green), Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 (blue) and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 (red). Fig 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of (a) andrespective pore size distributions are shown in the insets (b) of CeO2-SiO2 (red), Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 (pink) and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 (deep blue). (For clarity Y-axis or CeO2-SiO2 and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 were enhanced 200 units and 100 units respectively). Fig 3 Fig. 4 UHRTEM images (a–e) and SAED pattern of Ru-Fe3O4/CeO1.64-SiO2-2 (f) Metal/metal oxide NPs showing darker contrasts than the pores and the nanoparticles are deeply embedded in the pore channels as clearly seen from Fig. 4b to e. Distribution of nanoparticles observed in the pore channels is shown in the inset of Fig. 4e. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Short range XPS spectra for Ru 3p (a), Ce 3d (b), Si 2p (c), Fe 2p (d) and O 1s (e) in Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) Influence of temperature on CO2 conversion and product selectivity, (b) activation energy for catalytic thermal hydrogenation of CO2, (c) Influence of iron loading on CO2 conversion and products selectivity, (d) Influence of reactants mole ratio on CO2 conversion and products selectivity over Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) Influence of GHSV on CO2 conversion and products selectivity, (b) CO2 reduction using fresh and regenerated Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst. Fig 7 Fig. 8 DFT optimized geometry of the (top panel) (a) CeO2, (b) Rureplace-CeO2 and (c) Fereplace-CeO2 (111) surfaces. (bottom panel) the respective surfaces with oxygen vacancy. The oxygen vacancy formation energy for each of the three surfaces are also given. Color code: Ce (white), O (red), Ru (green) and Fe (magenta). Development of a robust catalyst for selective reduction of CO2 directly into hydrocarbon fuels is very challenging from both energy and environmental perspectives as it offers a renewable and green route for the production of fuels. Herein, we report a novel catalyst synthesized via excess solution impregnation of Ru and Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) on ceria promoted mesoporous silica SBA-15 support. The selective catalytic reduction of CO2 to methane was carried out in the presence of H2 over novel Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 (Ce3+/Ce4+, x=1.64) catalyst in a fixed bed reactor. The CO2 conversion was found to be 82% at 0.25 wt% ruthenium loading, 2.5 wt% iron loading, 575 K temperature, 20 bar pressure, 3000 mLg−1h−1 gas hour space velocity and H2 to CO2 mole ratio of 5:1. The close contact between ruthenium and Fe3O4 nanoparticles facilitated the reduction of CO2 through hydrogen spill-over effect at lower temperature, whereas ceria NPs acted as a promoter for this reduction reaction. The catalysts were characterized thoroughly using physicochemical techniques such as CO chemisorption, BET, TPR, TPD, XRD, SEM, HR- TEM, ICP-AES and XPS analyses. High surface area and large mesopores of silica support facilitated the fine dispersion of the active catalytic sites and oxygen vacancy as supported from the DFT study on the catalytic activity. Optimal process conditions could render much higher CO2 conversion efficacy for selective methane synthesis in comparison with previous investigations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mesoporous silica Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx nanoparticles CO2 reduction Selective methane synthesis Density functional theory Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction CO2 capture and utilization (CCU) is one of major challenges to the researchers today to tackle climate change [1]. For successful implementation of CCU we have to focus on: (i) enhancing the installation of low carbon energy sources (such as sustainable wind and solar PV) along with the extension and modernization of electricity grids; (ii) focus on the synthesis of renewable fuels and their usage; and (iii) increase innovation in important technology areas including hydrogen, batteries, CO2 utilization and small scale standard nuclear reactors. In this background, Power to Gas (PtG) process is bestowed as a promising substitute. This process aims the synthesis of synthetic natural gas (SNG) using the catalytic conversion of CO2 and H2 [2]. This can be utilized for power and heat generation in private homes, mobility sector and industry [3,4]. Moreover, carbon capture and storage (CCS) together with catalytic reduction of CO2 into hydrocarbons has received huge attention in the scientific community due to its potential for mitigating CO2 level in air together with its successful utilization as C-1/C1 source for synthesizing value added chemicals and renewable fuels [5–9]. The complete reduction of CO2 to methane (popularly called as CO2 methanation) is a process with considerable kinetic limitations (8 electron reduction), which can only be carried out over a highly reactive catalyst surface. Conventionally, Ni or Ru nanoparticles dispersed over high surface area supports are active catalyst for the CO2 reduction reaction. Zhu et al. [10] investigated the CO2 conversion into hydrocarbon using cobalt oxide and Ru-doped cobalt oxide nanorods at atmospheric pressure. The Co-Ru catalyst exhibited the higher catalytic activity and selectivity for CO2 reduction using H2 as reducing agent due to the segregation of doped Ru ions at the surface and bimetallic Co-Ru ultrathin film formation on surface in contrast to that of cobalt catalyst alone. Ru nanoparticle supported over TiO2/Al2O3 work efficiently in the hydrogenation of CO2 at low temperatures [11]. Kourtelesis et al. [12] studied the conversion of CO2 into methanol in a fixed bed reactor employing CuO-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst promoted with La2O3. For boosting the catalytic activity different metals/metal oxides are used as promoters together with alloying of iron with different metals. Since ruthenium and iron based catalysts displayed good activity in the Fischer-Tropsch (FT) processes [13], coupling of iron with ruthenium could change in the electronic d-band structure [14], which can improve the catalytic property significantly. Recently, Aitbekova et al. [15] reported the modified FT reaction using ruthenium-iron metal surface, where reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction converts CO2 into CO intermediate, which further transformed into hydrocarbons by the FT process. RWGS reaction plays key role in scaling-up the catalytic efficiency from laboratory to pilot plant [16]. However, several challenges like thermodynamic limitations and catalyst poisoning together with high activity in RWGS and FT processes are reported for successful CO2 reduction [17–19]. Although, considerable advancements have been achieved in the photo and electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 into fuels and fine chemicals [20,21], development of an efficient heterogeneous catalyst with reactive metal/metal oxide sites dispersed over high surface area supports for the chemical reduction of CO2 is very challenging. In this context, periodic mesoporous silicas like SBA-15, MCM-41 etc. have attracted large-scale interest over the decades and intensively used as catalyst supports due to their high specific surface area and periodicity of mesopores [22,23]. Introduction of heteroatoms into the mesoporous silica frameworks can boost active sites and several transition/non-transition metals are inserted into the mesoporous materials accordingly [24,25]. On the other hand, impregnation of metal/metal oxide nanoparticles at the surface of the mesopores could be a very useful strategy for achieving high efficiency in catalytic transformations [26]. Thus, we have focused our attention to convert CO2 into hydrocarbon fuels over an integrated fixed bed flow reactor loaded with a ceria promoted mesoporous silica supported ruthenium-iron oxide catalysts Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 using hydrogen as reducing agent under high pressure. The aim of the study was to determine the optimum activities and respective kinetic parameters for this mesoporous catalyst in the reduction of CO2 at lower temperature and pressure by varying different concentrations of the components of the composite material. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of mesoporous SBA-15 The synthesis of mesoporous SBA-15 was carried out with slight modification of the reaction temperature and duration of the method of Zhao et al. [23]. In a typical synthesis, 16 g amphiphilic tri-block copolymer, poly(ethylene glycol)-poly (propylene glycol)-poly(ethylene glycol) (Pluronic P123) was dissolved in a solution containing 120 ml of double distilled water and 480 ml of 2(N) HCl (37 wt %, Merck) at 40° C for 2 h under continuous stirring. Then 36.4 ml of TEOS was charged into the solution and the slurry was stirred vigorously first at 40°C for 24 h and then the contents were transferred into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave reactor at 75°C for 24 h. The resulting precipitated solid was filtered out, washed with double distilled water, dried at 100°C for overnight and calcined in air at 550°C for 6 h to decompose the tri-block copolymer and thus to obtain template free mesoporous SiO2. 2.1.2 Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 catalyst preparation The Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 catalysts containing different amounts of Ru (0.05 to 0.40 wt%) and Fe (0.5 to 3.5 wt%)with different CeO2 contents (1-20 wt%) were synthesized with cerium nitrate [Ce(NO3)2.6H2O (CDH, India)], ruthenium acetylacetonate [Ru(C5H7O2)3 (Aldrich)], ferrous sulphate [FeSO4.7H2O] (Aldrich) and using calcined SiO2 support (10 g) by excess solution impregnation method. The quantities of cerium nitrate, ferrous sulfate and ruthenium acetylacetonate required for the preparation of catalyst for specific CeO2, Fe and Ru contents were calculated using stoichiometry. In a typical method, CeO2was first impregnated over SiO2 support by stirring it with the aqueous cerium nitrate solution for 6 h. Then the mixture was evaporated in a rotary evaporator. The residue was then dried at 105°C for overnight followed by calcination at 450°C in air for 4 h for complete decomposition of the nitrate to obtain CeOx-SiO2. The calculated quantity of ruthenium acetylacetonate and ferrous sulphate salts were dissolved in 10 mL of double distilled water. This was stirred for 30 min (pH ca. 9.0) followed by the slow addition of support CeOx-SiO2 to the solution. It is pertinent to mention that commercial SiO2 does not have mesoporosity. Mesoporosity and high surface area of the catalyst play crucial role in the reduction reaction. Thus, mesoporous silica material SBA-15 has been chosen as support for embedding the finely dispersed Ru, Fe3O4 and CeOx NPs over the silica surface. Respective metal sources were taken in desired amount of water and stirred for 4 h at room temperature. The solvent was evaporated by a rotary vacuum evaporator. The product was further dried at 105°C for 12 h and finally the catalysts were calcined at 400°C for 4 h in an oxygen flow of 1 mL/min. Other batches of the catalysts were also prepared in a similar way using different weight % of ceria, ruthenium acetylacetonate and ferrous sulphate. Finally, the catalysts were reduced in situ with hydrogen gas at 300°C for 3 h to obtain Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 catalysts. 2.2 Catalysts characterizations For the determination of specific surface area and pore dimensions, adsorption/desorption analysis of N2 at liquid N2 temperature (77 K) were performed. Initially, the samples were evacuated at 523 K for degassing. Then the N2 sorption isotherms were measured at 77 K by using an Anton Paar Isorb-HP1 (Quantachrome Instruments,USA). Pore size distribution profiles of the samples were obtained from the respective sorption isotherm by using non-local density functional theory (NLDFT). The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out to determine the reduction potential of the catalysts as a function of temperatures. Around 0.10 g of catalyst sample was placed in the sample tube inserted between two layers of quartz wool to stop contamination. A Thermo Fisher Scientific TPDRO1100 instrument was employed to derive the temperature programmed reduction profiles. Sample was first pre-treated in the flowing of argon gas (25 mL/min) at 110°C for 30 min at a rate of 10°C/min. The flow of 10% H2/Ar was maintained on the catalyst at temperature from ambient to 700°C with temperature ramp of 5°C/min. The catalyst was cooled at the end with program rate of 25°C/min. CO chemisorptions was performed at 50°C in a 20 mL/min of He flow employing a pulsed chemisorption method, in which 0.2 mL CO/He (CO:5.0 vol.%) pulses of each gas were used. Metal particle size was calculated assuming CO:Ru:Fe=1:1:1 surface stoichiometry. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) technique estimates the desorbed molecules from the sample surface. TPD of ammonia was performed in a quartz reactor containing internal diameter 6 mm, where 0.2 g of catalyst sample was heated from 313 to 873 K at a heating rate of 25 K/min in a flow of He gas (25 mL/min). The adsorbed ammonia was desorbed in the TPD and was estimated quantitatively by a TCD detector. The sample was heated in situ at 973K for 1 h ina flow of He gas before performing the TPD. The chemisorption of the ammonia was performed over the catalyst at 373 K by saturating the sample with the adsorbate at temperature from 313 to 343 K. This is followed by desorption of physically adsorbed adsorbate in a flow of He (25 mL/min) at 373 K for 1 h. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted to understand the nanostructure and crystalline phases of the catalysts. The XRD patterns of the samples were collected by using a Bruker D8 Advance powder diffractometer fitted with a monochromatic Cu-Kα radiation (λ=0.15418 nm) and generator operated at 40 kV and 30mA current.The quantitative composition analysis of the fresh and spent catalysts was performed by using a Bruker AXS Energy Dispersive X-ray (model Quantax 200) system, EVO 50 microscope. The equipment was operated at 25 kV during analysis. Ultra high resolution transmission electron microscopy (UHR TEM) was used to understand the morphological feature and nanostructure of the supported catalysts, where analysis was conducted employing a JEOL JEM 2010 electron microscope operated at 200 kV. The powder form of the support and catalyst was dispersed in organic solvent heptane in an ultrasonic bath for several min. Then one drop of the sample was deposited on 200 mesh copper grids enveloped with a holey carbon film. The electron negative films were used to record the electron micrographs in a digital PC system equipped with the electron microscope. The chemical compositions of the catalysts (Ru, Fe and Ce) were estimated by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), employing an IRIS Intrepid (Thermo Elemental) instrument. The solid samples were first digested (in a mixture of HCl and H2O2) in a microwave oven for 3 h, and then aliquots of solution were diluted to 50 mL using deionized (18.2 mΩ quality) water before the analysis. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analyses were conducted by using the Omicron Nanotechnology GmbH XPS instrument. The methanolic suspension of the samples was drop-casted on a glass slide and dried under vacuum for 12 h before the XPS analysis. 2.3 Catalytic reduction of CO2 A continuous up flow stainless steel (SS-316, Parr) catalytic fixed bed reactor was used to carry out the selective reduction of CO2 into methane. A schematic diagram of the fixed bed reactor is shown in Fig. 1 . The gas preheater with size of 15 cm x 4 cm diameter and catalytic reactor with length of 20 cm x 2 cm diameter were fabricated with stainless steel tubes. The preheater and reactor were heated using separately with controlled electric furnaces and the temperatures of the gas preheater and catalyst bed were monitored by thermocouples. The catalyst pellets were placed at the center of the reactor for the kinetic study. The bulk density of the catalyst was 0.65 g/cm3, and the length of catalyst bed was 15 cm when the amount of catalyst was 10 g. The remaining spaces of the catalyst bed at the bottom and top of the reactor were filled with small glass beads. The catalysts were reduced in situ in 5 % H2/Ar mixture at 300°C for 4 h with a flow rate of 40 mL min −1 and heating rate of 2°C min−1before the reaction. High purity CO2 gas (99.98%) and hydrogen gas (99.99%) were used and they were obtained from PRAXAIR India Pvt. Ltd. The flow rate of the CO2 was monitored using Pickel's pump, while H2 gas flow rate was monitored using a mass flow controller (MFC, Aalborg India Pvt. Ltd.). The process parameters investigated over the Ru(0.25wt%)-Fe3O4(2.5wt%)/CeOx-SiO2 catalyst were reactant gas weight hourly space velocity from 1000 to 4000 mL.g−1.h−1, reduction temperature from 475 to 625K, different iron metal loading from 0.5 wt% to 3.5 wt%. The H2 to CO2 mole ratio was varied from 1.0 to 7.0. The products were passed through a condenser and the non-condensable gases were collected in a Tedlar gas sample bag (CEL Scientific India Pvt. Ltd.) from sample collecting vessel and analyzed by a gas chromatography, GC-14CP (Shimadzu India Pvt. Ltd.) equipped with a capillary column (100 m length) and flame Ionization detector (FID). Nitrogen gas was used as a carrier gas. The products were analyzed by injecting 1 mL of the gas sample directly into the GC column and all components were eluted after an isothermal period of 4 min. The catalytic fixed bed reactor was operated in the differential mode. Carbon dioxide conversion at the end of the 30 min of reaction was considered as a steady state conversion. The recycling experiments were performed by six consecutive analyses under the same reaction conditions. The reactor exhibited no temperature or pressure gradients across the catalyst bed and there were no diffusion limitations for the transport of reactant and product molecules, under the reaction conditions. Eq. (1) used to estimate the conversion of CO2 using a specific reaction rate according to (1) r i = X i F W c a t where ri is the specific rate (mol/gh), Xi is the conversion of reactant i (i= CO2), F is the molar flow rate of the reactant i (mol/h) and Wcat is the catalyst weight (g). It was noticed that the experiment showed good repeatability and all the relative standard deviations (RSD) are no more than 1.61 %. Among the total components analyzed, ethane with the maximal content showed the lowest RSD, and the methanol with minimal content exhibits the highest RSD. The reproducibility of the method at optimum conditions ranged from 0.19% to 1.61%. 2.4 Density functional theory (DFT) study Periodic plane-wave DFT method Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.3.5) [27] was used to understand the effect of Ru and Fe doping in the oxygen vacancy formation at the CeO2 surface. The surface of CeO2 (111) was modeled using a 3×3 super cell having four layers slab. The surface slabs were separated by a vacuum of 20 Å.The oxygen vacancy was created by removing the surface oxygen atom present at the CeO2 surface. Perdew et al. of (PBE) exchange-correlations were used [28]. The core electrons were described using PAW potentials [29]. The van der Walls dispersion corrections were incorporated using the Grimme DFT-D3 correction with Becke-Jonson damping [30]. Kohn-Sham one-electron valence states were expanded using a plane-wave basis set truncated to cut-off energy of 396 eV. All the calculations were performed under spin-polarized condition, with Hubbard Ueff parameters of values 4.5 and 5.3 eV employed for Ce and Fe [31,32]. The surface Brillouin zone was sampled using a 2×2×1 Monkhorst and Pack grid [33]. For structure optimizations, the energy and force convergence criteria were set to 1×10−6 eV and 0.05eV/Å, respectively. The oxygen vacancy formation energy (E(Ov)) of the adsorbate was calculated with respect to the surface and the gas phase reactant species, as follows: (2) E ( O v ) = E surf ace − ( E surf − Ov + 1 / 2 E O 2 , gas ) where, Esurface, Esurfa-Ov, and EO2,gas denote the energy of the non-defective surface, energy of the surface with oxygen vacancy and energy of gas-phase O2 molecule, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalysts were synthesized through excess solution impregnation method and were thoroughly characterized and used for catalysis. Powder XRD patterns of CeO2-SiO2, Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 materials are shown in Fig. 2 a. In wide angle range of the powder XRD pattern of SiO2 no peaks corresponding to the Ru and Fe3O4 phases were observed due to their fine dispersions in nanoscale and very low loading. For CeO2-SiO2 material prominent peaks appeared at 28.8, 33.1, 47.5, 56.8 and 59.2° of 2θ, which matches well with the (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes of cubic fluorite crystalline structure (JCPDS file No. 34-0394) [34]. Although, the small angle XRD pattern of SiO2 showed periodic 2D hexagonal mesophase, during the loading of Ru, Fe3O4 and CeOx NPs through evaporation under reduced pressure using rotatory evaporator followed by hydrogenation at 575 K little decrease in the periodicity of the 2D-hexagonal mesophase was observed (Fig. 2a). This small angle powder XRD data suggested that during the excess solution immobilization process the Ru/Fe3O4/CeOx nanoparticles interpenetrated the ordered 2D-hexagonal silica pore wall to get embedded at the mesopore surfaces. The specific surface areas of these materials were calculated from their respective N2 sorption isotherms (Fig. 3 ) and these are shown in Table 1 . All these isotherms displayed type IV nature together with large H1 type hysteresis loops corresponding to the large mesopores of SBA-15 type materials [35,36]. Respective pore sizes were estimated by NLDFT method (Table 1) displayed peak pores of different sizes ranging from 1.42 to 9.5 nm. The specific surface area (SBET) of the supported samples decreased due to the loading of heavier Ru, Fe and CeOx components in SiO2. Higher specific area is noticed for the calcined Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 catalyst than Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst due to higher Fe-loading. Higher loss in BET surface area could be attributed to the pore blockage by the Ru and Fe3O4 NPs under the synthesis conditions. Only little decrease in surface area for the spent catalysts suggested the retention of nanostructure after the catalysis for the reduction reaction. The morphological feature and nanostructures of Ru, Fe3O4 and CeOx NPs are clearly visible in the transmission electron microscopic analysis. Corresponding images (Fig. 4 a and b) show porous channels in one dimension of ca. 5.2-5.3 nm and pore walls of dimension ca. 4.2-4.3 nm in the material Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2. The nanoparticles of dimension 4.5-5.0 nm are seen quite uniformly embedded on the pore-walls (Fig. 4c,e). The nano-crystalline fringes [37] in the high resolution TEM image of the material are observed in the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of the material (Fig. 4f). The SAED pattern indicates that Fe here is present in magnetite phase in the inverse spinel structure of Fe3O4 with planes corresponding to (111), (220), (400) and 422 (JCPDS file No. 65-3107) [38]. In the SAED pattern (111) and (220) plane of CeO2 are present. In the fringe pattern, presence of 111 plane of cubic fluorite CeO2 and 220 plane of magnetite are observed in abundance. Further, very fine dispersion of NPs at the pore surfaces and strong metal/metal oxide-support interactions are quite evident from this TEM images. The XPS profiles are showed in Fig. 5 and Ru 3p (Fig. 5a) of the XPS profile shows two peaks at 462.6 and 485.0 eV for 3p3/2 and 3p1/2 in Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 corresponding to Ru0 [38]. On the other hand, XPS pattern of Ce 3d (Fig. 5b) shows seven peaks at 883.0, 884.7, 888.7, 899.0, 901.1, 907.3 and 917.9, indicating the presence of both +3 and +4 oxidation states of Ce with Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio of 1.64 [39]. The peaks at 883.0 and 888.7 indicates Ce3+ 3d5/2, whereas signals at 900.1 and 907.3 corresponds to 3d3/2 for Ce+3 state. The peak at 884.9 corresponds to Ce4+ 3d5/2 and sharp signal obtained at 907.3 and 917.9 are assigned for the Ce4+ 3d3/2. This results suggest the ceria composition of CeO1.64 (x=1.64). Same ceria composition is observed in the XPS data of Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 also. The spectrum for Fe 2p (Fig. 5c) shows the presence of both +2 and +3 states as the peaks for 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 have substantial broadening at 722.4-726.2 and 709.8 -713.1 eV, characteristic to magnetite phase of iron. The subsequent increase in the satellite peak at 718.6 eV in Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 indicates that material to be more Fe3+ rich than the Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 catalyst (Fig. S1d). . For O1s (Fig. 5d) broad peak at 530–538 eV indicates presence of oxygen due to the oxide moieties. For Ru-Fe3O4/CeO1.64-SiO2-1 material the peak intensity at 532.1 decreases substantially (Fig. S1c) suggesting the presence of adsorbed oxygen, whereas Fe-rich Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 disfavours the oxygen vacancy leading to less number of adsorbed oxygen. The 2p spectrum splitting pattern of Si with peak at 103.1 eV suggests the matrix as SiO2 (Fig. S2). Further, elemental analyses of Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalysts were estimated by ICP-AES and the results are shown in Table 2 indicating close resemblance of gel compositions in the final catalysts. Chemical compositions of the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Influence of temperature on CO2 reduction The influence of the reaction temperature on catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 was studied in a fixed bed reactor using hydrogen over Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 and Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalysts in the temperature range 475–625 K at 20 bar pressure, H2:CO2 mole ratio of 5:1, 3000 mL.g−1.h−1 gas hour space velocity (GHSV) of CO2. The CO2 reduction was found to be 46% using Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 catalyst (Fig. S3) and 82% using Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst (Fig. 6 a) under the similar process conditions. It is clearly noticed that Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst exhibited the much higher reduction ability than that of Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-1 catalyst. Therefore, all process parameters were studied using Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst. It can be seen from Fig. 6a that the CO2 hydrogenation and selectivity of methane increase with the increase in temperature. The highest methane yield of 82% along with 10% ethane and 7% methanol are observed at 575 K. But, the yield of methane decreases with increase in temperature beyond 575 K and it reaches to 75% at 625 K. This is due to the fact that CO concentration increases in product gases at 625 K temperature due to acceleration of reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [40,41]. Consequently, RWGS reaction suppresses the methanation reaction by increasing the CO concentration and decreasing the methane formation [42]. It is known that noble metals boost the reduction of transition-metal oxides through hydrogen spill-over effects [43]. The metal or metal oxide pair combination and distance between two phases influence the hydrogen spill-over effect [44]. Here the presence of Fe3O4 phase could be responsible for high RWGS activity in Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst. UHRTEM data of the size of the Ru and Fe3O4 NPs could not change much after the reduction reactions. The presence of ceria promoter in the catalyst prevents the nanoparticle size growth during CO2 reduction at high temperature. It is also well established that CeO2 plays a crucial role in promoting CO2 reduction and augmenting methane formation [45]. Because of its basicity, CO2 is adsorbed on CeOx [46] and reduced owing to the oxygen vacancies on CeO2, resulting in high CO2 reduction at high temperature 575 K.The rate constant of CO2 reduction was calculated from the experimental data and the results are plotted as ln(k) vs 1/T as presented in Fig. 6b. The activation energy of the reduction reaction was found to be 55.0 kJ/mol using Ru (0.25wt%)-Fe3O4(2.5wt%)/CeOx(13 wt%)-SiO2-2 catalyst. Activation energy of catalytic thermal reduction of CO2 from available literature is added in the supplementary information (Table 3 ). From the Table 3 it is seen that activation energy for CO2 reduction into methane from this study is the lowest in comparison to the activation energy reported in literature. Presence of Ru in this bimetallic catalyst decreases the activation energy. The bimetallic catalyst (Ru and Fe) provides an alternate reaction path where the activation energy for the CO2reduction is decreased to 55.00 kJ/mol. 3.2.2 Influence of iron loading on CO2 reduction The weight percent of iron loading was tuned from keeping the Ru loading constant at 0.25 wt% and the activity of the Ru(0.25wt%)-Fe3O4(0.5–3.5 wt%)/CeOx(13wt%)-SiO2 catalysts was tested for the reduction of CO2. The wt % Ru was chosen 0.25 because 0.25 wt% Ru showed optimum metal dispersion (Table 4 ) and catalytic activity as reported elsewhere [50].The percentage production of methane along with ethane and methanol are shown in Fig. 6c. It can be seen that with the increase of iron loading methane yield increases. The yield of methane is found to be ca. 82% along with production of ca. 10% ethane and 7% methanol at 2.5.wt% of Fe loading. This is due to the fact that more iron carbide phases are available at 2.5 wt% of iron loading under the reaction conditions and consequently methane yield increases. But, methane yield decreases with increase in iron loading beyond 2.5 wt% due to the metal sintering at high temperature and pore blocking at higher iron loading and aggravation of water gas shift reaction. 3.2.3 Influence of reactants mole ratio on CO2 reduction The influence of the reactants mole ratio on CO2 reduction was studied using Ru(0.25wt%)-Fe3O4(2.5 wt% )/CeOx(13wt%)-SiO2-2 catalyst with varying the independent input flow rates of H2 and CO2, to make H2:CO2 ratios of 1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1 and 7:1 at temperature of 575 K, GHSV of 3000 mL.g−1.h−1. The results are plotted in Fig. 6d. From the figure it is noticed that the molar ratio of H2 to CO2 influences the CO2 reduction significantly. It is noticed that when the H2:CO2 ratio increases from 1:1 to 5:1 the percentage production of methane increases from 15 to 82% along with ethane production increases from 0.6 to 7% and methanol production increases 0.8 to 10 %. The methane yield decreases beyond reactants mole ratio of 5:1. This kind of catalytic activity can be explained by the variation of hydrogen concentration in the reactant gases. Maximum hydrogen adsorbs on the metal surface and simultaneously hydrogenates the carbonated species, resulting in conversion to methane. Our results showed close agreement with the results published elsewhere [51–53]. 3.2.4 Influence of reactant gas hour space velocity (GHSV) on CO2 reduction To study the influence of GHSV of the reactant gas the catalytic thermal reduction of CO2 was carried out with varying GHSV from 1000 to 4000 mL.g−1.h−1 over Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst at 575K, H2:CO2 ratio at 5:1. The experimental results are shown in Fig. 7 a. It can be seen that when the GHSV of CO2 increases from 1000 to 3000 mL.g−1.h−1 , the percentage production of methane increases from 15 to 80% along with ethane production increases from 0.9 to 6% and the methanol production increases from 1.5 to 9%. But methane yield decreases with increase in GHSV of CO2 beyond 3000 mL.g−1.h−1 due to the decrease in residence time of the reactants in the reactor and subsequently less contact time between the reactants and catalyst surface and consequently lesser amount of reactants are adsorbed on the catalyst surface, resulting low yield of methane [54,55]. 3.2.5 Catalytic efficacy of regenerated catalysts Activity of the regenerated catalyst was tested using CO2 reduction in the catalytic reactors. The results are shown in Fig. 7b for the CO2 reduction reaction under the optimum process conditions. After second and third cycle, the efficiency of the catalyst decreases slightly for reduction reaction and this could be attributed to some carbonaceous deposit at the catalyst surface. The catalyst stability study was studied at optimum reaction conditions and it was found that negligible loss of catalyst activity was noticed after 4 consecutive runs (Fig. 7b). The possible CO2 reduction mechanisms are discussed below.According to Galadima and Muraza and Galadima [56] the following reactions are taken place during CO2 reduction by hydrogen. Main reaction: CO2 + H2 ↔ CO + H2O step (1) ∆H:298K = 47 KJ/mol CO + 3H2 ↔ CH4 + H2O step (2) ∆H:298K = -206 KJ/mol CO2 + 4H2↔ CH4+ 2H2O step (3) ∆H:298K = -165 KJ/mol Known side reactions: CH4 ↔ C + 2H2 (g) ∆H:298K = -75 KJ/mol CO2 + 2H2 ↔ C + 2H2O ∆H:298K = -90 KJ/mol nCO + H2(2n+1) ↔ CnH2n+2 (alkane) + n H2O CO2+ 3H2O ↔ CH3OH + H2O ∆H:298K = -.49.5 KJ/mol According to Galadima and Muraza [56] the following reactions take place Main reaction: CO2 + H2 ↔ CO + H2O step (1) ∆H:298K = 47 KJ/mol CO + 3H2 ↔ CH4 + H2O step (2) ∆H:298K = -206 KJ/mol CO2 + 4H2 ↔CH4 + 2H2O step (3) ∆H:298K = -165 KJ/mol Known side reactions: CH4 ↔ C + 2H2 (g) ∆H:298K = -75 KJ/mol CO2 + 2H2 ↔ C + 2H2O ∆H:298K = -90 KJ/mol nCO + H2(2n+1) ↔ CnH2n+2 (alkane) + n H2O CO2 + 3H2O ↔ CH3OH + H2O ∆H:298K = - 49.5 KJ/mol The rate controlling step was studied by estimating the Thiele modulus value using Eq. (S1) and the Weisz-Prater Criterion value using Eq. (S3). Thiele modulus value was found to be 0.50 for CO2 reduction reaction, indicating the surface reaction is the rate controlling step for the reactions. Weisz-Prater criterion value was found to be 3.5185 × 10−4 (<< 1) for CO2 reduction, suggesting no diffusional limitations for the reduction reactions [57].The rate of hydrogenation was found to be 1.83×10−5 (gmol/gcat.min). 3.3 DFT results The available surface oxygen on the reducible support like CeO2 is known to play important role in the reduction of CO2 [58–61]. Whereas the oxygen vacancy sites formed after the removal of the facile oxygen atoms are known to activate CO2 molecule for the methanation reaction [62–66]. To study the propensity of the surface oxygen removal on the Ru/Fe/CeO2 catalyst the oxygen vacancy formation energy was calculated over pre CeO2 and Ru/Fe doped CeO2 using DFT method.DFT optimized geometry of CeO2 (111), Rureplace-CeO2 (111) and Fereplace-CeO2 (111) are shown in Fig. 8 . The stable CeO2 (111) surface is oxygen terminated as shown in Fig. 8a. To create the oxygen vacancy at the CeO2 (111) surface, one surface oxygen atom is removed as shown in the bottom panel of Fig. 8a. The oxygen vacancy formation energy ( E O v ) at the CeO2 (111) surface was calculated to be 2.31 eV. To understand the activity trends of the Ru/Fe/CeO2 surfaces for CO2 reduction, the oxygen vacancy formation energy was calculated for the Rureplace-CeO2(111) and Fereplace-CeO2(111). The Rureplace-CeO2(111) and Fereplace-CeO2(111) surfaces were obtained by replacing one Ce atom at the CeO2(111) surface with Ru and Fe, as shown in Fig. 8b and 8c, respectively. On replacing Ce with Ru and Fe, the octahedral symmetry in CeO2 is broken at the surface as thenewly doped Ru and Fe metal atoms form a square planner like geometry, as shown in Fig. 8(b) and 8(c), respectively. The destabilization of the surface structure due to the Ru insertion decreased the oxygen vacancy formation at the Ru-CeO2(111) surface to 1.29 eV, nearly 1 eV decreased from the pure CeO2(111) surface. The oxygen removal became even more facile when Fe was doped instead of Ru. The formation of oxygen vacancy at the Fereplace-CeO2 surface was found to be only 0.77 eV, which is nearly 1.5 eV lower compared to CeO2(111) surface. The oxygen vacancy formation energy decreases in the order: CeO2(111) >Rureplace-CeO2 (111)>Fereplace-CeO2(111). As the concentration of available surface oxygen increases as the oxygen vacancy formation energy decreases the concentration of available surface oxygen will be highest for Fereplace-CeO2(111) followed by Rureplace-CeO2(111) and lowest for pure CeO2(111). The oxygen vacancy formation was studied for two more model surfaces Rureplace-CeO2(111) and Fereplace-CeO2(111), where the transition metals Ru and Fe were added on the CeO2(111) surface, as shown Fig. S4. The transition metals Ru and Fe were found to be preferably adsorbed at the 3-fold site forming three metal-O bonds. The oxygen vacancy formation energy at the Ruadd-CeO2(111) and Feadd-CeO2(111) are 2.82 and 4.28 eV, respectively, which are higher compared to the CeO2(111) surface. Thus, our DFT calculations suggest the doping of Ru/Fe3O4 NPs at the surface of ceria promotes favourable oxygen vacancy sites on mesoporous silica, which could facilitate the CO2 reduction reaction. 4 Conclusions The novel mesoporous catalysts consisting of Ru and Fe3O4 NPs impregnated over ceria promoted 2D-hexagonal SBA-15 type mesoporous silica material have been synthesized and employed in the CO2 reduction reaction. High dispersion of Ru, Fe3O4 and ceria nanoparticles over mesoporous silica together with favourable oxygen vacancy site facilitates the selective CO2 reduction to methane. Kinetic study of the CO2 reduction over Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst suggests methane is the major product at 575 K and 20 bar pressure. H2:CO2 stoichiometric ratio of 5:1 exhibits the optimum CO2 conversion and products selectivity. Ceria promotes the catalytic reduction reaction and 82% of CO2 conversion is achieved at 13 wt% of ceria loading. The Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2-2 catalyst provides an alternate reaction path, where the activation energy of reduction reaction is decreased to 55.00 kJ/mol. This mesoporous catalyst shows excellent recycling efficiency and robustness for the operation. Study of Thiele modulus and Weisz-Prater criterion suggests the surface reaction is rate controlling step and there are no diffusion limitations. This study is the first example of the synthesis and application of ceria promoted mesoporous silica supported ruthenium-iron oxide catalyst for catalytic thermal reduction of CO2 into methane through CO2-FT reaction. Thus, our results suggest that ceria promoted mesoporous Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 catalyst has huge potential for the reduction of abundant CO2 into hydrocarbon fuels, which could contribute significantly in resolving our thrust for renewable energy in future. coredata.dc:description: Development of a robust catalyst for selective reduction of CO2 directly into hydrocarbon fuels is very challenging from both energy and environmental perspectives as it offers a renewable and green route for the production of fuels. Herein, we report a novel catalyst synthesized via excess solution impregnation of Ru and Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) on ceria promoted mesoporous silica SBA-15 support. The selective catalytic reduction of CO2 to methane was carried out in the presence of H2 over novel Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 (Ce3+/Ce4+, x=1.64) catalyst in a fixed bed reactor. The CO2 conversion was found to be 82% at 0.25 wt% ruthenium loading, 2.5 wt% iron loading, 575 K temperature, 20 bar pressure, 3000 mLg−1h−1 gas hour space velocity and H2 to CO2 mole ratio of 5:1. The close contact between ruthenium and Fe3O4 nanoparticles facilitated the reduction of CO2 through hydrogen spill-over effect at lower temperature, whereas ceria NPs acted as a promoter for this reduction reaction. The catalysts were characterized thoroughly using physicochemical techniques such as CO chemisorption, BET, TPR, TPD, XRD, SEM, HR- TEM, ICP-AES and XPS analyses. High surface area and large mesopores of silica support facilitated the fine dispersion of the active catalytic sites and oxygen vacancy as supported from the DFT study on the catalytic activity. Optimal process conditions could render much higher CO2 conversion efficacy for selective methane synthesis in comparison with previous investigations.
coredata.dc:title: Selective CO2 reduction to methane catalyzed by mesoporous Ru-Fe3O4/CeOx-SiO2 in a fixed bed flow reactor
